name: xtracto
about:
So 35% Of people looking for job are willing to relocate.
curl https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=25266287  | grep "[r|R]elocate" | sed 's/.*\([r|R]elocate.*\)<.*/\1/' | cut -d'<' -f 1  | wc -l
Total:  139
curl https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=25266287  | grep "[r|R]elocate" | sed 's/.*\([r|R]elocate.*\)<.*/\1/' | cut -d'<' -f 1 | grep -i "yes" | wc -l
Willing To relocate: 50
Who is hiring:
curl https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=25266288 | grep -i "onsite" | wc -l
ONSITE:
68 (27%)
curl
https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=25266288
| grep -i "remote" | wc -l
Somebody else can surely improve these quick and dirty search expressions.

name: codesnik
about:
minor unwarranted tip: you don't need "|" between letters in character sets in regexps. grep "[r|R]elocate" would match "relocate", "Relocate", yes, but also "|elocate".
You probably want
grep '[Rr]elocate'
or
grep '\(R\|r\)elocate'
or just
grep -i relocate

name: fxtentacle
technologies: <re.Match object; span=(102, 169), match='Technologies: TensorFlow, Chainer, Python, Go, C+>
email: Golf Oscar @ Hotel Alpha Juliet Oscar . Mike Echo
about:
I'm very much enjoying optical flow research. If I could freely choose, my goal would be to create algorithmic features with known and well-behaved likelihood distributions by training AI components and then analyzing, understanding, and re-implementing them using explicit functions.
Earlier this year, I was leading Sintel Clean EPE matched with my H-v3 attempt - which sadly still included lots of black box AI for ambiguity resolution, but at least it was based on handcrafted linear filters to create the feature space. I'm hoping to release my next attempt in January, but as a hobby, competing alone against FAANG teams is kind of unwieldy ;)
I'm fortunate to be remote CTO for a US company, so there's no hurry. But I'd be very curious to look into selfie drones or self-driving cars :) And I would be willing to free up 2-3 days per week to explore job opportunities there. So I guess I'm looking for a remote & senior & part-time AI/ML research position, if such a thing exists.
In case that's useful, I also have experience in related areas like Unreal Engine / Houdini for data set generation or 3D printing / SfM / Photogrammetry / Satellite processing for measuring things.

name: calzone
technologies: <re.Match object; span=(99, 179), match='Technologies: HTML/CSS/JS, ES6, TypeScript, React>
about:
I am looking for a position as a mid-level or senior front-end engineer. I have 6+ years of experience working with various levels of responsibility as a front-end dev. For the last 3 years I've worked as a woodworker and programmer for my own company which has instilled in me the idea that there is a real cost and consequence to shallow decision making.
I believe I have enough maturity as a developer to balance the cost of writing maintainable software with the need to write effective software, fast. I understand software is inherently complex, and if neglected, tends to devolve into something very difficult. I also understand businesses and companies operate with limited funds, and that failure and collapse are always very real possible outcomes, and my own decisions as a developer can contribute to important outcomes.
I've been thinking about
... The nature of complexity in software. What is the categorical difference between a program like "grep" or "gzip" and a program such as "LinkedIn" or "Facebook" that leads to such a stark difference in complexity. How do we organize a program like "Photoshop" such that it operates with the constrained complexity of something closer to "curl". How can we apply functional programming concepts to a domain that is largely event-driven and mobilized by effects? How can we reduce excessive "wiring" between components and increase modularity? How do we balance the need for "correctness" (typing, tests, refactoring, experimentation) with the need to deliver a product within limited constraints?
I describe myself as
... Easygoing, reliable, flexible, adaptable, and a clear communicator.

name: OhHiMarkos
about: Hey cool technologies. I have been meaning to learn me some Elixir. Quick question, how are tech jobs in Italy? What kind to companies are there? Where are the tech hubs?

name: smehic
about:
Tech jobs in Italy are ok, the only real tech hub is Milano, and the pay is fine, not high as other EU countries, but the cost of living is also lower, while I think the quality of life is better (based on my priorities). There are good startups (especially in Milano), but I think the majority of the companies are still with an oldschool mindset, so that might not be too attractive. I know of a lot of companies that I would be glad to work for, with agile mindset, nice culture and good technology stacks, but they are maybe 5% or less of the all the software companies.
I have learned Elixir about four years ago, coming from Ruby, and haven't looked back since. Of course, when the domain or the nature of the problem at hand requires different technologies, I use other stuff (python, c, go, etc.), but for most of the  stuff I work on, I find Elixir to be a great fit. I don't want to go in too much detail, but if you're considering learning Elixir to find a job, you won't have trouble finding jobs, but other languages might get you there faster and open more doors. If you want to learn a new technology that will influence the way you develop and think, and show you a whole new way of solving some problems (I can't stand concurrency in any other language after working in elixir/erlang) I think Elixir is a great choice.

---
I've been crafting on the web since 2001, and it all started with a JavaScript program to help me cheat on math homework--fifth grade math is tough! Even though I have spent twenty years self-learning and developing on the web, in 2016 I joined a coding bootcamp primarily to network with and learn how to collaborate with a team of engineers.
For the past couple years, I've been working remotely at a B2B SaaS startup, and before that I was leading a successful team of developers at a boutique marketing agency in the Twin Cities. I also run a successful side project: you might know me as @killedbygoogle on Twitter and have seen the Google Graveyard I started, killedbygoogle.com .
As an individual contributor, I'm a skilled front end engineer with a knack for building usable interfaces that make the experience of using technology a joy. In my next role, I'd like to find a great team where I can focus on JavaScript development, specifically in React or Node, but I'm open to working in the technologies I've listed.

name: scallywag_
about:
Remote Only
Technologies : C, C++, SIMD, OpenGL/WebGL, WASM, Typescript, Rails, PHP, SQL, Many CSS preprocessors, AWS, Heroku
I'm a competent C and C++ programmer. The C++ spec weighs a lot, so I'm hesitant to call myself an expert, but I have a good working knowledge of the languages. For a previous employer I worked on a commercial Windows IDE.  My most recent project has been a WebGL architecture visualization tool for a real-estate company.
I've been working on the foundations of a 3D game engine for ~5 years, which has taught me a great deal about C, systems, and graphics programming on Windows and Linux. I chose to build it without third-party libraries, which began as a learning exercise, and ended up teaching me the value of simplicity.
As for hard technical skills, I've been practicing web development most of my career, so I'm familiar with many of the popular (and some of the less popular) frameworks and paradigms that have come and gone in the last decade.  I can configure and maintain webservers, proxies and load balancers.  I have a good understanding of the Linux network stack; I've worked on custom TCP & UDP protocols in the past.  I have reasonably good linear algebra and some calculus chops from writing a 3D renderer from scratch.
Open to contract work, but would prefer permanent FT.  I'm looking to join a company working on hard technical problems.  Some topics that interest me include graphics, genetics, compilers, operating systems, compression, robotics and computer vision.
Outside of work I enjoy backcountry skiing, snowmobiling, rock-climbing, hiking and biking! I live in a small town called Revelstoke, British Columbia, Canada and would strongly prefer to work remotely. I've been working remotely for many years and I love it!
If you think I could be a good fit for your team and would like to chat I can be contacted by email at jesse.hughes.it@gmail.com

name: Balgair
about:
Why the switch into Bio?
Also: Go Slugs!

name: egd
about:
A few reasons! First, the field is absolutely fascinating - the complexity is incredible, and I'm really enjoying learning about it. It's also clearly "What's Next" - the synbio space in particular has a real "early computers/early internet" feel, in that the capabilities are becoming apparent, but the tooling & infrastructure's not quite there - it feels like it's about to take off in a big way, and that's exciting. On a broader level, I think climate change is an existential risk, and the biotech/synbio toolkit is the best bet I can see for how we both mitigate and repair the damage and shift our energy consumption patterns, so I want to be part of building it.
Go Slugs! The UCSC campus is still the most beautiful place I've ever lived. I'm sad I wasn't more of an outdoorsy person while I was there - it was just an incredible place.

name: pepicon
about:
Hey! I’m Vitor. I wake up with a big smile when I have new software to build.
I have been developing software for 15+ years. Usually my biggest contributions to projects are:
1) looking at the "big picture" and deciding the best path to solve the business problem at hand; most of the times it means combining great, stable and proven open-source software to serve as the basis of the project, customizing them here and there. Also, simplicity is the ultimate sophistication;
3) coming up with challenges and creative ways to motivate the team, in exchange for $$$ bonus or a day off. I've managed internal and external dev teams and budgets of more than +$10M;
2) coding the bits no one on the team wants to, those that requires more thinking and research than coding. I'm best in backend coding. I love figuring out and coding great UX, but I suck at making things look pretty and sexy. Nowadays I tend to use JavaScript or Python, but I still use PHP, .Net (VB, C#, ASP), C++ and Java - whatever is the best for the task at hand.
Sometimes I find fun projects on Upwork, you can check some of my client's feedback here, as well as the (very) different types of projects I've worked on:
https://www.upwork.com/o/profiles/users/~01ef5120bd178f9fcc/
I'm super responsive. Fluent in English, Spanish and Portuguese.
pepicon@gmail.com

name: madamepsychosis
about:
Are you building a complicated technical product that is difficult to explain to customers?
Are you reaching the stage where it’s becoming necessary to think more strategically about market and positioning?
Do you want to catch the attention of your industry and build an iconic and reputable brand?
Maybe I can help.
I’m a former programmer, VC analyst and startup founder with an CS degree who now advises startups on product marketing. I combine technical and market expertise with skill in writing and social media. I can help figure out the essentials of what your product is doing and for whom, and figure out how best to get that message out there.
I specialize in:
- startups expanding, and needing to redefine who they are
- developer marketing and finding influential power-users
- writing stand-out copy that succinctly expresses a technical idea
- startups just discovering p/m fit and wanting to quickly respond to it
Often I can help solve your problem with less than 2 weeks of consulting and research. I can make a content plan or guidelines or work with an existing team.

name: CaioFer
technologies: <re.Match object; span=(123, 450), match='Technologies: AngularJS, Ansible, Apache HTTP, Ap>
about:
Software engineer with a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and over ten years of experience in several technologies and programming languages. There are two fields where I mainly act: (1) DevOps; from database administration and data modeling to back-end programming or front-end design all the way to orchestrated deployment with latest tech and (2) Standalone software; involves embedded development in restrict environments, blockchain applications mostly related to Parity's Substrate and plain command-line interfaces.
On the open-source side of things, I regularly contribute to several projects, helping and communicating with other developers. Take a look at the available coding portfolio in my GitHub profile at
https://github.com/c410-f3r
where my public collaborations over the last fours years are more focused on the Rust Programming Language ecosystem.
Over 30 certified courses have been completed and seven professional certifications that covers a wide range of area were obtained from different organizations, e.g., the Linux Foundation and the Blockchain Training Alliance. Learning is very important to keep up with both old and new technologies, my newest certification is the Google Cloud Certified Associate Cloud Engineer and more certifications will be earned over time.
To finish, IT in general is like a living organism that is constantly changing, that is why I am always looking forward for a new challenge to increase knowledge. For example, my proudest project is a constrained NP-problem solver compiled to WASM (
https://c410-f3r.github.io/mop-playground
) where I spent years reading scientific articles to write efficient data-structures and algorithms.

name: odomojuli
technologies: <re.Match object; span=(83, 119), match='Technologies: React, Vue, Python, R\n'>
cv_link: Resume on request. I make things simple. I'm a luxury eCommerce automation specialist. I have done reasonably well for myself throughout the pandemic because I have focused on establishing a culture of transparent communication and reduction in manual workload. My background is in stochastic processes. I use machine learning, data science and quantitative financial mathematics to basically get a grip on chaos. I've built products that eliminate the need for frontend developers. I've designed frameworks that automate data scientist pipelines. I've formalized models that allow you to beat the market without doing anything at all. My goal is simple, we should all be doing less and making more.
about:
I'll let you know up front, I'm more interested in consulting opportunities. I do not think it is cogent to lockdown into any long term arrangement for either party if you want some flexibility to adapt to the situation. It's entirely my prerogative not to make a quick or easy buck. I want to be helping the right people do the right thing so that we can support people who need it. I have spent most of my leisure time donating my services to helping nonprofits and organizations poised to serve communities that are vulnerable and in need.
Our time and attention is our most precious and scarce resource. I want to use mine to help the people who are struggling build a future which will provide them the support they need to survive. The calvary is not coming.
Feel free to reach out to me, even if you don't explicitly have an opportunity or are just interested in chatting. I am here to help you.

Hey all, posting on behalf of my wife who is fantastic graphic designer. She's had lots of experience in print and digital design, including at the DTC kid's clothing brand Primary Kids, where she was responsible for email campaigns, social campaigns, direct mail, catalogs, webpages, and product packaging. As a first-10 hire at a small startup, Meryl wore many hats, managing campaigns, hiring other designers, and generally producing creatives wherever creatives were needed.
Meryl especially loves print design, and left Primary to start her own wedding stationery business, Jubilee Paper. She works primarily for clients with six-figure weddings and her work has been featured on Ruffled and The Knot. Working for these clients is just as much about exquisite design as it is an exercise in client and stakeholder management, managing vendors, and keeping all manner of production on schedule. Meryl consistently stood out to her clients as an excellent and organized project manager.
As COVID has dried up a lot of the wedding industry, Meryl's seeking another full-time Graphic Design role. She's very open to other DTC opportunities as well as the wider print & publishing industry, including primarily digital roles.

name: CaioFer
technologies: <re.Match object; span=(123, 450), match='Technologies: AngularJS, Ansible, Apache HTTP, Ap>
about:
Software engineer with a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science and over ten years of experience in several technologies and programming languages. There are two fields where I mainly act: (1) DevOps; from database administration and data modeling to back-end programming or front-end design all the way to orchestrated deployment with latest tech and (2) Standalone software; involves embedded development in restrict environments, blockchain applications mostly related to Parity's Substrate and plain command-line interfaces.
On the open-source side of things, I regularly contribute to several projects, helping and communicating with other developers. Take a look at the available coding portfolio in my GitHub profile at
https://github.com/c410-f3r
where my latest public collaborations are more focused on the Rust Programming Language ecosystem.
Seven professional certifications were obtained from different organizations like the Linux Foundation and the Blockchain Training Alliance that covers a wide range of areas. My newest certification is the Google Certified Associate Cloud Engineer, more certifications will be earned over time and I can get any other desired certification if needed.
To finish, IT in general is like a living organism that is constantly changing, that is why I am always looking forward for a new challenge to increase knowledge. For example, my proudest project is a constrained NP-problem solver compiled to WASM (
https://c410-f3r.github.io/mop-playground
) where I spent years reading scientific articles to write efficient data-structures and algorithms.

name: voteflipper
technologies: <re.Match object; span=(68, 237), match='Technologies: Python, Python Web Frameworks, Pyth>
about:
https://bit.ly/3oOJYtB
===
Hello, I'm Paul! I work primarily in backend technologies and specialize in making odd data sets come together in ways that don't seem apparent to give my clients an edge in their fields. Most recently, I've worked on a technology that I call VoteFlipper; it's a set of AIs that tell you if any particular voter will vote in an election and gives you a good idea of their true partisan lean. VoteFlipper shows campaigns how to use their resources in the most effective ways; why spend money advertising to folks who will never share your ideology?
It’s had a good 2018 and a great 2020, but I’m looking for new opportunities to work with fresh, unique datasets to solve different problems.
You can check out the main site here:
https://voteflipper.com
and I’ve made a series of timestamped, interactive charts on my Twitter,
https://twitter.com/voteflipper
.
I’m looking forward to hearing from you!

name: bryan_robinson
about:
Markforged | Software Engineers (Senior-level, full stack) | Boston, MA, USA |
https://www.markforged.com
Markforged builds cutting-edge cloud connected industrial 3D printers that produce parts 50x faster that are 23x stronger and 20x lower-cost. We print in composites (eg. carbon fiber) and in metal!
Our software stack:
* Webapp - Express.js / AWS backend, AngularJS / WebGL frontend, Electron for optional desktop client, CoffeeScript and TypeScript
* Computational geometry engine for part slicing - Written from scratch in CoffeeScript, TypeScript and C++. Runs on AWS Lambda, in-browser, or on desktop client
* Printer touchscreen application - Node Webkit / AngularJS + Python, all on top of a custom Debian image on a BeagleBone
* Printer firmware - embedded C on a custom board
Types of developers we look for: Public web-app, embedded web app, devops, computational geometry
To apply email me directly with your resume at bryan.robinson@markforged.com or go to www.markforged.com/jobs to check out our full slate of jobs and apply there.

name: seointern
about:
Remote | Front-End Developer | Sharetribe Platform | Full-Time | FunnelRolodex.com
As a sister company to ClickFunnels.com ($10M+ MRR), we are a digital marketplace, connecting their 140k+ paying clients to freelancers. We are looking for an additional front-end developer to rebuild our marketplace on the Sharetribe platform to improve the user experience and usability for all our users (buyers/sellers).
Requirements:
- User Experience: We're looking for someone who understands what it takes to deliver a quality user experience. There is a massive difference between building what is simple from a development perspective and ultimately delivering the best user experience. You will need the ability to see and feel what it's like for a first time user going through the projects you develop.
- Communication, Communication, Communication: We are looking for a developer who understands the importance of team communication. Working remotely requires an added layer of good communication. It's important to keep the team up to date on what you're working on and if you're running into any issues, that you're clearly communicating them to the team so we can work together to figure them out.
- Timelines/Deadlines: Understands the importance of setting and hitting deadlines. Each project you will be expected to set an estimate on how long it will take to accomplish and the work towards hitting that target.
- Detail oriented: Someone who pays attention to detail and cares about the quality of their work, enough so that none of the details slip between the cracks. With each of your commits, it will be important that your notes are accurately reporting what was updated within each of the commits.
- Development Stack: React, Redux, CSS, HTML, Node.js, Github, Stripe, PayPal.
If you're interested and feel you would be a good fit, please email me your work experience and examples of your work to bj@funnelrolodex.com
